awd_titl_txt: Discovery of the mechanisms enabling morphological and functional integrity of the plant ER
awd_abstract_narration:
In addition to providing commodity materials and fuels, plant cells are an essential source of oxygen and nutrients to humans. Like all eukaryotes, the life of plants depends on the function of specialized structures, known as organelles that populate the subcellular environment. An essential organelle, whose function and morphology are largely conserved across eukaryotes, is the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). This project seeks to understand how the ER establishes and maintains its functional and morphological identity. As the ER is at the core of the cell's biosynthetic machinery, and because significant variation in ER biology exists among eukaryotes, studying the ER within model plant systems provides an essential foundation to improve plants as primary providers of useful biomolecules and to support life on this planet. This project on the Arabidopsis ER will also provide new fundamental knowledge that will influence the study of other organisms that share mechanisms underlying ER biogenesis with plants. In addition, it will provide societal benefits through education of the next generation of scientists, engagement of high-school students and teachers in research, and by communicating discoveries in plant science and their impact on the society through outreach activities.

A central question in cell biology is how organelles establish and maintain their identity. Due to its rich, mutable morphology, the ER is a wonderful model to explore this question. The ER adopts an intricate web-like architecture via cytoskeleton-driven remodelling and anchoring of subdomains to the plasma membrane (PM). However, the mechanisms underlying ER shape as well as differentiation and function of ER-PM subdomains are largely unknown, especially in plants. The research will capitalize on the discovery of novel components of the Arabidopsis proteome that control ER morphology and interaction with heterotypic membranes, including the PM. Using a suite of advanced live-cell imaging approaches, functional genomics analyses and mathematical modeling, the project will characterize a novel plant ER shaper, define the molecular composition of the ER subdomains interacting with the PM and determining how such subdomains influence the biosynthesis and deposition of the extracellular matrix. The results will help create a new paradigm of plant ER structure and function. Since ER integrity and function are inextricably linked and the ER presents species-specific features, this research promises to significantly advance basic understanding of plant ER architecture and function, and provide a framework for comparative insights into ER biology among eukaryotes.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this award is to define the molecular underpinnings of the integrity of the plant endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and their functional connections with cell growth. The ER is an essential organelle that is key to the process of secretion and intracellular membrane traffic. The ER synthesizes one third of the cellular proteome, essential lipids and primes the glycosylation of secretory proteins. Therefore, the ER allows the cell to communicate with the external environment. The ER assumes a unique reticulated structure, and past research in our lab and others has contributed to the identification and characterization of proteins involved in the establishment and maintenance of the ER structure. Defects in the ER organization hamper growth, but the underlying mechanisms are yet largely unknown. This NSF award has tackled this significant problem whose solution may provide tools to improve crops’ productivity and yield. To pursue our goals, we trained post-graduate and undergraduate-level personnel and published our results in peer-reviewed journals in addition to disseminating findings at scientific conferences and issuing a patent.

In our research we were able to study new and yet uncharacterized proteins, and we were able to implicate already known proteins in new processes. Specifically, we found that a new protein, named SHE1, interacts with a component of the cell’s cytoskeleton and an ER shaper. Furthermore, we found that SHE1 interacts with the machinery responsible for cell degradation. Our results suggest that SHE1 may be involved in the maintenance of ER homeostasis and support the hypothesis that SHE1 may be involved in degradation of the ER network. In addition, we were able to demonstrate that certain proteins associated with the ER membrane, known as VAP27 proteins, interact with endocytic machinery components, which are responsible for the internalization of plasma membrane (PM) and extracellular materials into the cell. Biochemical and genetic characterization of the VAP27 proteins led us to the findings that they are responsible for homeostasis of endocytic processes. These results are significant because they connect the ER with essential processes, such as endocytosis, which are not seemingly connected. In addition, we studied mutants that exhibit an altered structure of the ER. One of these mutants has a defect in the production of branched-chain amino acids. Characterization of this mutant led to the new discovery that alteration of the homeostatic levels of branched chain amino acids in plant cells leads to the uncontrolled activation of an essential protein, known as TOR, which inputs nutrients’ availability to control growth. We found that TOR misregulation leads to alteration of the cytoskeleton components that maintain ER network integrity. Therefore, our results connect an essential growth regulator with an unexpected source of nutrients. Our study marks significant milestones in plant cell biology by making two novel connections, namely that in plant cells TOR responds to the availability of branched chain amino acids, and second, that the integrity of the ER morphology relates to the activity of TOR. Therefore, our data support the new model that disruption of TOR activity influences plant cell growth via an alteration of the structure of the ER and the cytoskeleton.  

In conclusion, this award has enabled us to make highly significant discoveries that have contributed to the understanding of the functional connection of the integrity of an essential organelle with plant cell growth at the molecular level through mechanisms and pathways, which had not been previously considered related with each other.
